item.title: Fixing a reveresed axis
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(blogdown) Data comes from week 13 of #TidyTuesday. seattle_pets <- read_csv( "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2019/2019-03-26/seattle_pets.csv") ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## license_issue_date = col_character(), ## license_number = col_character(), ## animals_name = col_character(), ## species = col_character(), ## primary_breed = col_character(), ## secondary_breed = col_character(), ## zip_code = col_character() ## ) seattle_pets %>% filter(!species %in% c("Goat", "Pig")) %>% count(species, animals_name) %>% group_by(species) %>% top_n(10) %>% mutate(animals_name = replace_na(animals_name, "Unkown")) %>% ggplot(aes(animals_name, n)) + geom_col() + labs( title = "Top 10 animal names among Cats and Dogs", y = "", x = "Name of Animal" ) + coord_flip() + facet_grid(~species) + theme( panel.

item.title: Generating multiple ggplot plots using purrr
item.description: At my work we often create visualizations that look very similar but have slight differences when it comes to aesthetics, axis limits, labels, and other attributes. What I would traditionally do is reuse code from one visualization to another simply by copying and pasting, but as is common emphasized in data science, one should avoid copying and pasting more than two lines of code. For that reason I decided to turn my code into a function that could reuse code without the need for copying and pasting.
